content: The Bush Administration released The Budget of the U.S. Government, Fiscal Year 2008 on February 5, 2007, in compliance with the statutory requirement. The budget documents include detailed information such as historical data, budget authority, outlay and receipt data, and the Administration's economic forecast. The budget documents provide descriptions of the Administration's policy proposals and expectations from FY2007 through FY2012, as well as historical data on appropriations, outlays, and revenues. The congressional budget process begins once the Administration submits its budget to Congress, with revisions often made during deliberations. Congress revises budget proposals as economic conditions change. FY2008 budget resolution adopted on May 17, 2007. House and Senate committees consider appropriation bills. By August 5, House passed all twelve bills. Senate passed Homeland Security bill in July. In FY2007, the Senate passed four appropriations bills by September 30. A continuing resolution was passed to fund the government until November 16. Congress approved the Defense bill providing $459 billion. The President vetoed the Defense bill (H.R. 3222, P.L. 110-116) providing $459 billion in non-emergency budget authority, citing funding levels and policy disagreements. This veto threat complicated the appropriations process. Congress passed funding extensions until December 21, including an omnibus appropriations bill (H.R. 2764) incorporating 10. On December 19, Congress passed an omnibus appropriations bill (H.R. 2764) that combined 10 regular appropriations bills into the State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill and a fourth continuing resolution (H.J.Res. 72). The President signed a fourth continuing resolution (P.L. 110-149) funding government operations through the end of the year. On December 26, the President signed the Consolidated Appropriations Act of FY2008 (P.L. 110-161), providing $555 billion in discretionary budget authority. The nation's aging population and increasing healthcare costs are leading to rising deficits and a federal debt burden that is spiraling out of control.
